qas.question: What is considered the same as matter?
What does special relativity show mass can do?
What can be created or destroyed?
What changes during the transformation of matter?
What does not change in an open system?

context: Matter should not be confused with <b0_0>mass<b0_0/>, as the two are not quite the same in modern physics. For example, mass is a conserved quantity, which means that its <b4_0>value<b4_0/> is unchanging through time, within closed systems. However, matter is not conserved in such systems, although this is not obvious in ordinary conditions on Earth, where matter is approximately conserved. Still, special relativity shows that matter may <b1_0>disappear by conversion into energy<b1_0/>, even inside closed systems, and it can also be created from energy, within such systems. However, because <b2_0>mass (like energy)<b2_0/> can neither be created nor destroyed, <b3_0>the quantity<b3_0/> of mass and the quantity of energy remain the same during a transformation of matter (which represents a certain amount of energy) into non-material (i.e., non-matter) energy. This is also true in the reverse transformation of energy into matter.
